title: SoftwareSourceCode
description: Computer programming source code. Example: Full (compile ready) solutions, code snippet samples, scripts, templates.

type.$comment: This is a special property analogous to JSON-LD's `@type` keyword.

id.$comment: This is a special property analogous to JSON-LD's `@id` keyword.

identifiers.description: Any kind of identifier for any kind of Thing.
identifiers.$comment:
Some identifiers have specific properties e.g the `issn` property for
the `Periodical` type. These should be used in preference to this
property which is intended for identifiers that do not yet have a
specific property. Identifiers can be represented as strings, but
using a `PropertyValue` will usually be better because it allows
for `propertyID` (i.e. the type of identifier).

about.description: The subject matter of the content.
about.$comment:
Consistent with https://schema.org/about, this property allows for
linking to one of more `Thing` nodes. This could for example include
a `Person` (e.g for a bibliography) or a `DefinedTerm` (e.g. for
subject areas the creative work relates to).

authors.description: The authors of this creative work.

content.description: The structured content of this creative work c.f. property `text`.

dateAccepted.$comment:
This is not yet a schema.org property but the term is used
[in Dublin Core](http://purl.org/dc/terms/dateAccepted).

funders.description: People or organizations that funded the `CreativeWork`.

fundedBy.description: Grants that funded the `CreativeWork`; reverse of `fundedItems`.
fundedBy.$comment:
This follows the proposal [here](https://github.com/schemaorg/schemaorg/issues/2258)
for a property that is the reverse of `fundedItems`.
It is an any because a `CreativeWork` may have been funded through more than
one `Grant`.

genre.description: Genre of the creative work, broadcast channel or group.

keywords.description:
Keywords or tags used to describe this content.
Multiple entries in a keywords list are typically delimited by commas.

isPartOf.description: An item or other CreativeWork that this CreativeWork is a part of.

licenses.description: License documents that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.

maintainers.description: The people or organizations who maintain this CreativeWork.
maintainers.$comment:
A maintainer of a Dataset, SoftwareApplication, or other CreativeWork.
A maintainer is a Person or Organization that manages contributions to,
and/or publication of, some (typically complex) artifact. It is common for
distributions of software and data to be based on "upstream" sources.
When maintainer is applied to a specific version of something e.g. a particular
version or packaging of a Dataset, it is always possible that the upstream
source has a different maintainer. The isBasedOn property can be used to
indicate such relationships between datasets to make the different maintenance
roles clear. Similarly in the case of software, a package may have dedicated
maintainers working on integration into software distributions such as Ubuntu,
as well as upstream maintainers of the underlying work.

parts.description:
Elements of the collection which can be a variety of different elements,
such as Articles, Datatables, Tables and more.

references.description:
References to other creative works, such as another publication,
web page, scholarly article, etc.

text.description: The textual content of this creative work.

title.description: The title of the creative work.

version.description: The version of the creative work.
version.$comment:
In this case `string` is listed as an alternative before `number` to
avoid semantic version numbers e.g. `1.0` being parsed, and subsequently
encoded, as `1` thereby resulting in loss of information.

codeRepository.description:
Link to the repository where the un-compiled, human readable code and related
code is located.

codeSampleType.description: What type of code sample: full (compile ready) solution, code snippet, inline code, scripts, template.

runtimePlatform.description:
Runtime platform or script interpreter dependencies (Example - Java v1,
Python2.3, .Net Framework 3.0).

targetProducts.description: Target operating system or product to which the code applies.
